questions.question: What does IEEE 802.11 define?
questions.explanation: IEEE 802.11 is the standard that defines wireless LAN technology, commonly known as WiFi.

questions.question: Which frequency band does 802.11b use?
questions.explanation: 802.11b operates in the 2.4 GHz frequency band with speeds up to 11 Mbps.

questions.question: Which 802.11 standard operates exclusively in the 5 GHz band?
questions.explanation: 802.11a operates only in the 5 GHz band, offering less interference but shorter range.

questions.question: What does SSID stand for?
questions.explanation: SSID is the network name that identifies a specific wireless network.

questions.question: Which wireless security protocol is most secure?
questions.explanation: WPA3 is the latest and most secure WiFi security protocol with enhanced encryption.

questions.question: What access method does 802.11 use to avoid collisions?
questions.explanation: CSMA/CA is used in wireless networks to avoid collisions before they occur.

questions.question: Which 802.11 standard supports both 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz?
questions.explanation: 802.11n operates on both 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz bands for flexibility and performance.

questions.question: What is the maximum theoretical speed of 802.11g?
questions.explanation: 802.11g operates at 2.4 GHz with a maximum speed of 54 Mbps.

questions.question: What mode allows wireless devices to communicate without an access point?
questions.explanation: Ad hoc mode enables direct device-to-device communication without a central access point.

questions.question: Which wireless standard is also known as WiFi 6?
questions.explanation: 802.11ax, branded as WiFi 6, offers improved speed and efficiency in congested areas.
